results.headline: ‘Alone’ Review: Catch Her if You Can
results.summary_short: An emotionally fragile young woman takes a terrifying road trip in John Hyams’s bare-bones thriller.

results.headline: ‘The Way I See It’ Review: Hailing Days Not Too Far Past
results.summary_short: Pete Souza, the White House photographer for the Obama administration, casts a warm eye on the past and a cold eye on the present in this Dawn Porter documentary.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Way I See It

results.headline: ‘Blackbird’ Review: The Goodbye Girl
results.summary_short: Susan Sarandon plays a dying matriarch hosting her family one last time in Roger Michell’s vacant tear-jerker.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blackbird

results.headline: ‘Antebellum’ Review: Look Away, Dixie Land
results.summary_short: Janelle Monáe stars in a muddled attempt to revisit the horrors of American slavery.

results.headline: ‘The Devil All the Time’ Review: Down-Home Livin’ and Dyin’
results.summary_short: In this period drama, Tom Holland plays a country boy surrounded by Gothic ghouls, including Robert Pattinson’s preacher man.

results.headline: ‘The Secrets We Keep’ Review: Confessions All Around
results.summary_short: A possible case of mistaken identity has a dark fallout for two couples in post-World War II America.

results.headline: ‘#Alive’ Review: From Great Graphics, to Graphic
results.summary_short: A laid back gamer is homebound with no food, no weapons, and zombies knocking at the door in this spirited Korean twist on siege movies.

results.headline: ‘Buoyancy’ Review: Enduring Horrors on the Sea, and Struggling to Survive
results.summary_short: In this sobering, moving drama, a Cambodian teenager runs away from home and is sold into slavery on a Thai fishing boat.

results.headline: ‘Coastal Elites’ Review: Confined Confessions
results.summary_short: This collection of monologues written by Paul Rudnick initially for the stage, has been adapted for the screen.

results.headline: ‘Suspension’ Review: Roads to Nowhere
results.summary_short: This documentary looks at a stretch of road in Colombia known as “the springboard of death.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Suspensión

results.headline: ‘I Am Woman’ Review: Singing Against Sexism
results.summary_short: Unjoo Moon’s film is a superficial hustle through the career of Helen Reddy and the recording of her most famous song.

results.headline: ‘Black Boys’ Review: Young Lives in the Balance
results.summary_short: This documentary addresses the dehumanization of Black boys by attempting the reverse: reconstructing them to show they are worth the care they are denied.

results.headline: ‘Our Time Machine’ Review: A Picture of the Past
results.summary_short: In this documentary, the Chinese artist Maleonn enlists his aging parents, both artists themselves, in an ambitious memory play.

results.headline: ‘Unpregnant’ Review: Friendship Is a Long and Winding Road
results.summary_short: Former besties reunite for a road trip in this teen buddy comedy, which is the second movie this year to feature young women crossing state lines to obtain an abortion.

results.headline: ‘Red, White & Wasted’ Review: Dirty Driving
results.summary_short: A beloved swampland subculture is under threat in this raucous yet melancholy documentary.

results.headline: ‘Space Dogs’ Review: No Dogs Go to Heaven
results.summary_short: This documentary uses the lives and legends of Moscow’s street dogs to present a brutal vision of humanity and nature.

results.headline: ‘Jimmy Carter Rock & Roll President’ Review: A Musically Enlightened Commander in Chief

results.headline: ‘Rent-A-Pal’ Review: You Don’t Want to Borrow This VHS Tape

results.headline: ‘Sibyl’ Review: Diagnosing Problems, and Creating More
results.summary_short: A troubled psychotherapist becomes unhealthily embroiled in a patient’s life in this unhinged melodrama.

results.headline: ‘The Social Dilemma’ Review: Unplug and Run
results.summary_short: This documentary from Jeff Orlowski explores how addiction and privacy breaches are features, not bugs, of social media platforms.
